coredata.dc:title: Vibrational energy relaxation of high-density HBr fluid in the 186–366 K range
coredata.dc:creator: Chesnoy, J.
Ricard, D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
We have measured the vibrational lifetime of dense fluid hydrogenn bromide slightly above the critical temperature and of liquid-phase hydrogen bromide along the liquid—vapor coexistence curve. The results obtained above the critical temperature are interpreted in terms of a contribution of van der Waals dimers to vibrational relaxation. The liquid-phase results are interpreted in terms of the Delalande and Gale model using the same approximations as in the case of hydrogen chloride.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 92, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 October 1982 VIBRAT10NAL ENERGY RELAXATION OF HIGH-DENSITY HBr FLUID IN THE 186-366 K RANGE J. CHESNOY and D. RICARD Laboratoire d'Opfique Quantique duCIVRS, Ecole Polyieclimque. 91128 Palaiseau Cedex, France Received 26 July 1982 We have measured the vibrational bfeunie of dense fluid hydrogen bromide suchily above >he critical tcinpcratuic and of liquid-phase h> drogen bromide along ihe liquid-iapor coe\istence cune. Tile re5UllS oblaincd above Ihe criIlCal lempCra- ture arc interpreted in terms of a contribution of van derWaalsdinierstovibr.ilional relaxation. Thi; liquid-phase results aic inicrprcied m lermsof the Delalande and Gale model using lhesanie3pprD\imaiions3sin llie case of hydrogen cliloridi*. 1. Introduction The study ofvibrational energy relaiation in the liquid (or dense fluid) phase is still a subject of im- portance. The main question one would like to an- swer is the following: is this deexcitation process still due to isolated binary collisions at hquid densities'* Theoreticians have fought for years about this impor- tant issue. Assuming the isolated binary collision (IBC) model to be valid and assuming furthermore the deexcitation probability per collision to be densi- ty-independent, one is then left with the calculation of the collision frequency. A model developed recent- ly by Delalande and Gale [1] has found, despite the simple appro'umations it involves, a large range of applicability for simple diatomic molecules such as hydrogen [2] and its isotopes [3] or nitrogen [4] as well as for simple tnatomic molecules such as CO^ orCSi [1,5]. On the other hand, there may be prob- lems in trying to fit experimental results obtained on liquid oxygen [6] and hydrogen at very high densities [4] with this model. The Delalande and Gale model allows the calcula- tion of the density dependence of the lifetime. In par- ticular, it allows us to compare the lifetime measured in the liquid phase and in the gas phase (assuming thermal equilibrium). In a previous publication [7], we reported measurements of the lifetime of the first eiciied vibrational level of a polar diatomic mol- ecule ~ hydrogen chloride - in the liquid phase and in the dense fluid above ihe critical temperature. The liquid-phase results could be interpreted in terms of the Delalande and Gale model with a few further ap- proximations. The results obtained above the critical temperature confirmed the predictions of Ewmg [8] about the role of the dimers, a problem which is strongly tied to the abovemcntioned thermal equilib- rium assumption. Our results on liquid-phase hydrogen chloride were compared to the low-density gas-pliase results obtain- ed by Zitiel and Moore [9]. The low-density gas- phase relaxation constant has also been measured as a function of temperature by Ziltel and Moore in the case of hydrogen bromide (9j. In order to lest the validity of the assumptions used in the interpretation of the HC1 results, we have extended our work to a study of HBr. In the present paper, we report on the measurement of the vibrational lifetime of hydrogen bromide in the liquid phase (along (he liquid-vapor coexistence curve) and in the dense fluid above the critical temperature. We will see that these new results confirm the HC1 ones and that an interpretation following the same lines, namely the role of dimers and the Delalande and Gale model, leads to very good agreement. 0 009-2614/82/0000-OOOO/S 02.75 1982 North-Holland 449 Volume 92, number 4 1. Experimental CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 3. Results 29 October 1982 Since the lifetime we measure is in ihe nanosecond range, we must resort to a subnanosecond technique for the measurement. The technique we use is the well-known Raman technique as modified by Spanner et al [10]. An infrared picosecond pulse populates the v = 1 level, a second delayed picosecond pulse probes ilie population ofihis level via spontaneous anti-Stakes Raman scattering. The apparatus has been described [7]. The excita- tion and probe pulses are derived from a single laser pulse delivered by a mode-locked Nd : YAG laser pulse selector and amplifier system operated at a 2.5 Hz repetition rate. The infrared e\citation pulse is generated by single pass parametric amplification in iwo lithium niobaic crystals. It is luneu 10 the peaK of the first overtone (2.06 ^m). In the case of hydro- gen bromide, the first o\enone does not correspond 10 simultaneous transitions [11] (or pair absorption) so that the molecules are probably not directly ex- cited in the u = 1 level. But we know that, due to rapid vibraiion-to-vibration transfer, the molecules end up in ihe u = 1 level within a tune which is much shorter than the lifetime to be measured. The probe pulse, of wavelength 0.532 (Lim, is created by second-harmonic generation in a KDP crysldl. A corner cube pnsm mounted on a transla- tion stage provides a variable delay between the exci- tation and probe pulses. The scattered anu-Stokes photons are collected at 90 in a large collection solid angle, filtered by interference fillers ana detected by a gated phoiomultiplier tube. Every other shot, the excitation beam is blocked and the background signal associated with the probe pulse is measured. The sample preparation is the same as in the case of hydrogen chloride. After several distillations, HBr is contained in a sealed glass bulb. Commercial hy- drogen bromide was purchased from Air Liquide. The whole etpenment is controlled by an Apple II micro- computer. The density of liquid HBr, along the liq- uid-vapor coexistence curve, is not so well known as in the case ofHCl. We chose what we think is the best guess among several publications [12]. Fig 1 shows the reciprocal lifetime 1/7^ as a func- tion of density above the critical temperature. The critical pressure of HBr being rather large and the ann-Stokes signal being weak, we had to limit our- selves to measurements of T) at a single temperature 2-3 K above the critical temperature 7';;. The results shown in fig. 1 represent the average over several mea- surements. Four samples were studied with densities ranging from 0.65p,; to 1.57?,; where p^ is the critical density. This critical density is 0.807 g/cm3 or 0.60 X 1022 molecules/cm3. The critical temperature and pressure are respectively 363 K and 87 aim. Fig. 1 shows the temperature dependence of the vibrational lifetime T] of liquid HBr along the liquid-vapor coexistence eunre from ihe inpie point to the critical point. Each dot is the result of one measurement. Several samples have been used. Point A corresponds to an interpolation of the results ob- tained slightly abo\e T^. The lifetime varies from ^1.15 ns near the inple point to "=4.76 ns at the criti- cal point. As can be seen from fig. 1, the accuracy of the measurement is much lower in the case of HBr than in the case of HC1. This is due first to the weak anii- Stokes signal, especially for high temperatures and low densities. This is also due to photons scattered off thermally excited molecules (spontaneous anti- Stokes scattering at thermal equilibrium could readily be observed, especially at high temperatures). Above Fig. 1. Reciprocal lifetime l/7'i (dol5) versus density sbghuy above the critical temperature. Each dot corresponds to an average over several measurements 450 Volume 92, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 October 1982 T, (-) rent results relies, as in the case of HC1 [7), on the contribution of van der Waals dimers in the high-densi- ty range under study here. Non-excited dimers are created in termolecular collisions of two monomers M and a collision partner X k{ M+M+X^ MM+X. (1) ^d Vibrationally excited dimers M'M can be formed in similar collisions involving an excited molecule M* instead of a non-excited one. One may also have e\- change processes such as 200 250 300 3!0 J^ Fig 2 Vibrational lifetime FI of hquidH Bras a function of lemperatun; 7'along ihe tosiiaienec cur'e from the tnple point lemperature T'( to the cnlical tempcratyre 7'c. The ex- perimental results are given by the dots. Point A at r= 7'c was c\tracted from fig 1. The solid line has been calculated using cq. (13) with the value ^= 140 K. (2) MM+M'^M'M+M. K Vibrational energy relaxation may occur via a con- ventional binary collision M'+X M+X (3) room temperature, this gives rise to most of the back- ground signal which has to be subtracted from the raw signal in order to get the true signal correspond- ing to laser excitation. or via predissociauon of an e\cited duner l/r M'M M+M. (4) 4. Discussion 4.1. Dense fluid above the critical temperature In the case of HC1 [7], the results were accurate enough to conclude unambiguously that the recipro- cal lifetime 1/7^ was proportional to the density p over the density range under study. In the present case of HBr, the results are not accurate enough to reach unambiguously such a conclusion. But at least, from fig. 1, we have a hint that such a linear relation- ship also holds. We recall that an identical gas-like behaviour was also observed in the case of H^, close to 7'c, by Delalande and Gale [13] up to p 1.8 X lO^cm-3. In the present study, the measured rate constant A= 1/pTi is^3.5 X 10"14 cm3 s~1 whereas the rate constant measured in the low-density gas phase at the same temperature by Zittel and Moore [9] is 1.87 X 10" 14 cm3 s~1. Our interpretation of these diffe- Ewmg [81 has shown how this leads to two different regimes: in the low-density range [(.k^ + K)p <^ 1/r) k-k^, rS) whereas in the high-density range [(k^ + K)p > 1/rj *=^+A-,=A-t,c+(2/r)<:,-/A-d, (6) Ay being the contribution of van der Waals dimers to vibrational energy relaxation. In the same way as in the case of hydrogen chloride, we believe that, in their experiment, Ziltel and Moore observed the low-density behaviour. On the contrary, our supercritical results reported here correspond to the high-density regime. We then conclude that for HBrarr^Tc A-bc^l^X lO^cm3 s-1 (7) and A-bc+fev^S.aX lO-'-'cn^s-1 . (8) This is consistent with expected values for the equilibrium constant k^k^ and the predissociation 451 Volume 92, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 October 1982 (9) lifetime r. According to Stogryn and Hurschfelder [14] A-t/fcd is of the order of 10~22 cm3. According to Ewing [8], T is of ihi; order of 10"^ s. Such consider- ations lead to an expected value for k^ in good agree- ment with observation 4.2. Along the liquid-vapor coexistence curve We interpret our liquid phase results shown in fig. 2 in the same way as we interpreted the HC1 results [71. According to the Delalande and Gale model, v,hich assumes an isotropic intennolecular potential consisting of a hard core of dimeter o and an attrac- tive part of depth e, one has, at the same temperature r'^ = (i/p1'^)^"/^)"'!, where g(a) is the pair distribution function and A-p^ is the rate constant (1/pT,) measured m the gas phase. We make the same approximations in the calcula- tion of^oF-.gCo)1"! and h^. Firsi,^)6" is given by (10) vihere Ag is Boltzmann's constant and where e is as- sumed of the form (11) li is the permanent electric dipole moment of the HBr molecule. The second term ofeq. (11) is the thermal average over the orientations of two molecules of their dipole dipole interaction energy. Second, we assume that^o)1"! is given by the hard-sphere result, i e. the Carnahan and Starling formula [15] ^0)"1=(1-^)/(1-^3, (12) where T} = ^ npa^ is the packing fraction. The Delalande and Gale model assumes thermal equilibrium in particular for excited dimers. There- fore ^35 is in fact k^ + Ay, the high-density rate constant. Only k^ is known from the work ofZittel and Moore [9]. As our third approximation, we as- sume that the ratio of fc^c + *v to k^ is a constant C. From the supercritical results, C = 1.87. We then end up with the formula 2fi4 1 (1 -ri~)3 1 | 0 ________ Ck^^W 3a^r-] nP- (13) which iseq.(19)ofref. [7], with only one adjustable parameter, 9. In the numerical calculation, we use the values a = 3.5 A (instead of the Lennard-Jones diameter given by Hirschfelder et al. [ 16] which is doubtful and probably underestimated when compared with HC1 and HI) and fi = 0.80 D. Fig. 2 shows the very good agreement between the experimental results and the lifetime calculated using eq. (13) with 0/A-g = 140 K. 0 is thus found to be larger for HBr than for HC1. This was to be expected since 0 comes mainlv from dispersion forces. The comments we made in ref. [7] about this very good agreement between theory and experiment could be reproduced here, in particular, the comment about our crude way of taking into account the mo- lecular anisotropy.The IBC models usually assume that the deexcitation probability per collision P is the same in the liquid phase and in the gas phase. This as- sumption could be questioned in the case of hy- drogen halides for which rotation is known to play a very important role in vibrational energy relaxation in the low-density gas phase and is hindered in the liquid phase. But, in a recent publication [17], we reported our measurements of the vibrational lifetime of liquid-phase deuterium chloride along the liquid- vapor coexistence curve. From these results we con- cluded that rotation still plays the same important role in vibrational relaxation even in the liquid phase. 5. Conclusion Using the Raman technique as modified by Spanner et al., we have been able to measure the vibrational lifetime of dense fluid HBr slightly above the critical temperature for various densities and of liquid HBr all along the liquid-vapor coexistence curve. The supercritical results confirm, as in the case of hydrogen chloride, the predictions of Ewing concern- ing the role of van der Waals dimers at sufficiently high density. The liquid phase results were inter- preted in terms of the Delalande and Gale model with some further approximations. We emphasize the fact that our HBr results were interpreted following the same lines as in the case of HO with very good agree- ment between theory and experiment. 452 Volume 92, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 October 1982 We therefore have a consistent picture for vibra- tional energy relaxation in dense fluid hydrogen hali- des. In particular, for these molecules, an isolated binary collision model (the Delalande and Gale one) is quite successful in explaing the liquid-phase results. Fig. 2 shows the very good agreement between the experimental results and the lifetime calculated using eq. (13) with 0/A-g = 140 K. 0 is thus found to be larger for HBr than for HC1. This was to be expected since 0 comes mainlv from dispersion forces. The comments we made in ref. [7] about this very good agreement between theory and experiment could be reproduced here, in particular, the comment about our crude way of taking into account the mo- lecular anisotropy.The IBC models usually assume that the deexcitation probability per collision P is the same in the liquid phase and in the gas phase. This as- sumption could be questioned in the case of hy- drogen halides for which rotation is known to play a very important role in vibrational energy relaxation in the low-density gas phase and is hindered in the liquid phase. But, in a recent publication [17], we reported our measurements of the vibrational lifetime of liquid-phase deuterium chloride along the liquid- vapor coexistence curve. From these results we con- cluded that rotation still plays the same important role in vibrational relaxation even in the liquid phase. 5. Conclusion Using the Raman technique as modified by Spanner et al., we have been able to measure the vibrational lifetime of dense fluid HBr slightly above the critical temperature for various densities and of liquid HBr all along the liquid-vapor coexistence curve. The supercritical results confirm, as in the case of hydrogen chloride, the predictions of Ewing concern- ing the role of van der Waals dimers at sufficiently high density. The liquid phase results were inter- preted in terms of the Delalande and Gale model with some further approximations. We emphasize the fact that our HBr results were interpreted following the same lines as in the case of HO with very good agree- ment between theory and experiment. 452 Volume 92, number 4 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 29 October 1982 We therefore have a consistent picture for vibra- tional energy relaxation in dense fluid hydrogen hali- des. In particular, for these molecules, an isolated binary collision model (the Delalande and Gale one) is quite successful in explaing the liquid-phase results. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: We have measured the vibrational lifetime of dense fluid hydrogenn bromide slightly above the critical temperature and of liquid-phase hydrogen bromide along the liquid—vapor coexistence curve. The results obtained above the critical temperature are interpreted in terms of a contribution of van der Waals dimers to vibrational relaxation. The liquid-phase results are interpreted in terms of the Delalande and Gale model using the same approximations as in the case of hydrogen chloride.
